name: Chromeos-developer-setup
tagline: A developer setup guide for Chrome OS (Chromebooks).
body:
_I've recently switched to Chromebook as my main laptop. I have come across several different possible options available to developers. I have detailed them below._

**First things first, turn off [OS verification](#turn-off-os-verification-on-chromebooks). After you turn off OS verification, all of the below are now open to you as options:**

## Option 1: Ultra-minimalist Setup

* **Description**: Use Chrome OS terminal to access Linux 3.4 environment and install a package manger for minimalist dev box. 
* **Time to Complete**: 5 - 10 minutes.
* **How**:
  * Open developer's console (crosh terminal) by pressing **<ctrl> + <alt> + t**
  * Type in **shell**
  * You are now able to work with the Linux environment. For development purposes, this probably means Vi & SSH'ing to a remote server.
  * If you are feeling too limited but don't want to install Ubuntu or the like, try Option 2. 
  * Recommended: you can install Chromebrew, the Chrome OS package manager. 
  * It will provide several useful packages such as make, git, python, ruby, vim, openssl, curl, etc. Full list can be found here.


## Option 2: ChrUbuntu Setup

* **Description**: Dual boot Ubuntu 12.04 and Chrome OS separately. I have found this to be more tedious to initially setup and more suited for those who prefer to boot into one OS at a time. 
* **Time to Complete**: 15 - 30 minutes
* **How**: 
  * Follow this excellent [tutorial](http://chromeos-cr48.blogspot.com/2012/04/chrubuntu-1204-now-with-double-bits.html)  
  * If you want to install Ubuntu on an SD card [follow this tutorial](http://chromeos-cr48.blogspot.com/2012/12/so-you-want-chrubuntu-on-external-drive.html)


## Option 3: Crouton Setup

* **Description**: To me, this is the best option because it involves just one command to install, immediate switching between Chrome OS & Ubuntu. Also allows you to combine Option 1 with this option.
* **Time To Install**: 20 - 30 minutes
* **How**:
  * Download crouton here via chrome.
  * Open developer's console (crosh terminal) by pressing <ctrl> + <alt> + t
  * Type in shell
  * Run the installation 
  * For XFCE type in: sudo sh -e ~/Downloads/crouton -t xfce
  * For Unity type in: sudo sh -e ~/Downloads/crouton -t unity
  * Near the end of the installation, you will be asked to pick a username and password. Now you should be able to switch between Chrome OS and Ubuntu seamlessly. To switch to Ubuntu: 
    * If you installed unity, run **sudo startunity** 
    * If you installed xkfce, run **sudo startxfce4**
    * Shortcut for switching OSes for ARM based Chromebook: **<ctrl>+<alt>+<shift>+<forward> (F2)** 
      * Replace the back key (F1) with the forward key (F2) to switch back
    * Shortcut for switching OSes for Intel based Chromebook: **<ctrl> + <alt> + <back> (F1)**
      * Replace the back key (F1) with the forward key (F2) to switch back.

## Option 4: The Cloud "Koder" Setup

  * **Description**: This option relies on using an online service koding.com that hosts free VMs for you which you can access via a very nice web interface and a chrome app called terminal. I plan on writing a short blog post on this setup soon.
  * **Time**: 5 - 10 Minutes
  * **How**:
    * Sign up at koding.com for a free account. You will get an Ubuntu virtual machine and a sub-domain name.
    * Install the terminal chrome app. Once installed, open it. It will allow you to access your Koding VM right from a browser tab with a full-page terminal application. 
    * I have also heard great things about nitrous.io as an alternative, however I have not personally tried it myself.

## Option 5: Windows on Chrome OS

  * **Description**: I have not tried this yet but I have heard this is possible and in the works. Expect more on this topic soon.
  * **Time to Install**: Unknown
  * **How**:
    * If you are feeling brave, try this oldie but goodie: http://gizmodo.com/5257386/how-to-install-windows-7-on-almost-any-netbook
    * Here's another: http://www.sevacall.com/blog/2013/04/s/computer-repair/install-windows-on-chromebook/


***

# Turn off OS Verification on Chromebooks

  * **Description**: Allows you to experiment with the Chromebook by giving you access the developer's console and OS services. 
  * **Time to Complete**: 5 - 10 minutes
  * **FYI**: This process does wipe your machine of any local data. But being a cloud-based device, any data in Google services will be restored automatically upon reboot. 
  * **How**:
    * Turn off Chromebook
    * Press and hold <esc> + refresh (F3 key) + power button
    * Release the power button but hold the others until you see an error prompt that says "Chrome OS is missing or damaged". Press Enter.
    * At the next screen, you will be notified that OS verification is Off. Press <ctrl> + d
Device will now be wiped and in 3 to 10 minutes your Chromebook will restart
    * **Done!** 
    * Note: Whenever your device reboots from now on, you will be prompted to turn OS verification on. Doing so will kill a kitten. You don't want to hurt a kitten, do ya? I didn't think so.
